posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

In the past, when there's been 'ultimate questions' which were impossible to answer, it often required a radical shift in how we looked at the question.
I don't think we're going to understand consciousness with our current toolkit. It obviously isn't "just electric signals", else computers will be able to develop consciousness.
There are forces in the universe which are absolutes, like gravity, or magnetism. We'd be wiser to look at consciousness as being something of a similar nature; a force which allows some type of coding to manipulate matter on ridiculously small scales.
This code, however - unlike gravity - looks like it's able to also evolve and adapt as the systems it governs becomes more complex.

Think forward to a hypothetical future. If humanity on Earth reaches some type of singularity and becomes a nervous system of our planet, which one event would be the turning point? Then think what systems and processes would've led to this event? If we can entertain this thought experiment, we might be able to to the same going back in time, and smaller in scale.

The Tudor period is seen when England got out of medievalism and became a modern nation. The roots of the British navy and its mercantile power originated from Henry VIII's shipyards which Elizabeth would later put to good use. It's also when England became Anglican since there's still a bit of anti-Catholic flavor in their society.

I think the English Civil War is a touchy subject for a class-defined society like England. You still have the living descendants of the Cavaliers as well as the Roundheads around. It'll give too many ideas of republicanism amongst the commoners.

It's the same reason why pre-1066 England is criminally overlooked. The Anglo-Saxons were a respected people whose proselytizing of their pagan Germanic cousins on the continent were invaluable to the world. Walpurgis Night in Central Europe is named after Saint Walpurga whom I bet only a handful of everyday English know who he is. The same for Saint Boniface whose venerated in Germany. And their artwork and crafts were sought after. But this was all lost and nearly forgotten thanks to the Norman Conquest and later Plantagenets.

>>14409371
Modern scholarship and genetic testing paints a more complex picture of the Anglo-Saxon invasions of Britain.

There were of course massacres and depopulation when it arose, but it appears that many Englishmen today have Brythonic roots like the Welsh, Cornish, and Bretons. It's the eastern parts of England that have a strong Germanic imprint (as well as from the Danes and Norwegian invaders later on). So basically when the Germanics set root in Britain, the Romano-Britons assimilated into Englishness.

As for the Bretons, it was actually the threat of Irish raids that compelled them to leave Cornwall and Devon (remember it's right across Ireland) to Armorica. It wasn't until the late 10th century when the Anglo-Saxons subdued Cornwall that Brittany would receive a ton of Cornish refugees to settle.

To be fair about pre-Alfred the Great, England had several petty kingdoms and tribal warlords running around from the 400's to the early 800's when the Vikings landed on Britain. It'd be hard to fully explore all of them. Though Offa of Mercia was a contemporary of Charlemagne the Great and was regarded as the greatest Anglo-Saxon king before Alfred.

And it's criminal that Aethelstan is not given more recognition. He was the first king of a unified Anglo-Saxon realm. England was his creation after reconquering the Danelaw and incorporating the Anglo-Scandinavians as his subjects.

The frame of thought that linguistically alien cultures to Indo-Europeans must have been colonies from some arcane island in the Aegean is a silly one, and reeks of Victorian historiography. The more reasonable explanation is that they, much like the Basques, were part of a complex of cultures (like the Indo-European one which supplanted it) which ranged in a straight line from Shetland to Sicily starting in the Neolithic.

I'm way more interested in the ethnogenesis of the Italics, since in my own headcanon Rome was a synthesis of Etruscan high culture/administration and Celtic bellicosity.

The same circumstances seem to be present in the ethnogenesis of the Hellenes who were likely a cultural fusion of the shrewd Pelasgians and the warlike Balkan tribes who spoke "Proto-Greek" dialects.

The moment Jesus came back to life his sacrifice stopped being significant. A sacrifice has significance because it is the intentional destruction of something important to the person or group making the sacrifice as a thank you, plea or as a sign of regret to whatever they are sacrificing to. You value god more than what you sacrificed. As an example, sacrificing my pet would have far more significance than sacrificing something like a can of coke because that can of coke is easily replaceable while the pet is not. Even if I did get a new cat, dog or whatever the connection would be different therefore maintaining the uniqueness of the sacrificed pet. If my pet magically came back to life it undermines what it means to be a sacrifice as I have lost nothing while gaining whatever I sacrificed them for. It's also an issue that Jesus' sacrifice was made pre-emptively. Going back to the pet example, would it have the same significance if I made the sacrifice before doing something wrong? No, if anything it would be worse since by pre-empting the sin it proves I want to do the sin more than I care about the pet as I am making no effort to not do the sin.

TL;DR: Jesus' sacrifice isn't significant because by pre-empting people's sins after his death and coming back to life he stops being a sacrifice.

> The literature on the voting behaviour of women during the late Weimar period also points to Protestant piety as a possible linchpin in the Nazi vote. Scholars have long maintained that women retained greater rates of piety than men, going so far as to cast the 'feminization of religion' as one of the most important transformations in modern European cultural life. > second, after 1930, the percentage of women in the Nazi vote rose sharply. Childers argues that in 1932, especially, the party made enormous gains among Protestant women, to the extent that women outnumbered men in the Nazi constituency for the first time (at least in those areas where votes were tabulated by sex). Falter is more qualified in his analysis,demonstrating that women outnumbered men in the 1932 Nazi constituency only in Protestant towns with populations under 2000 - where religiosity was generally higher.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Well, what's the alternative? Holy scripture is a piece (or multiple pieces) of language and as such needs human interpretation. Even the most hardcore historicist literalist (ofc KJV only so stuff like problems of translation and the size of the biblical canon can be ignored) will either at one point or the other have to ask himself "wtf does that even mean" or just shrug it off so it becomes totally meaningless dead scripture.

Take something like the genealogies of tribes or the measurements of the temple, why should a literalist care about any of that today? From their point of view, god is talking about things in the past that happened long ago, but the moment they ask the question "and what does that have to do with me?" they start to interpret. Or think about the classic example, the agreements between Mark, Luke and Matthew. When you discover that whole passages are pretty much copy-pasted, your natural reaction is to ask yourself why that is. The Bible itself doesn't tell you "oh btw I gave you three almost identical versions so you could see the same out of different perspectives" or "oh yeah I say it three times to proof it really happened exactly like this", so even the historicist literalist has to come up with SOMETHING or end up just ignoring it away.

Biblical criticism is one method to get an understanding out of biblical text. Yes, there's a lot of guesswork and overanalyzing involved, especially if it's done in a shitty way or with a certain agenda. There are other ways to interpret scripture as well, sometimes they can work pretty well in a complementary way, depending on what you're trying to do or find out. But shitting on biblical criticism just because it appears to be downplaying stuff by contextualizing it doesn't help you in your endeavour of trying to make sense out of scripture.

1. Perpetual Virginity -- the statements regarding Jesus having brothers can be read either way linguistically, there is typology which could apply to Mary, Eze. 44:2, and there is intertexual comparison of Mary with the ark of the covenant in Luke. What we need is a reason to read these things in this way. First we should note what perpetual virginity actually is, which is that Mary was a virgin before, during, and after birth. The "during" means that her virginity remained physically intact as Christ's birth was of a miraculous nature. If this did not occur, then it means that Christ damaged his own mother's physical virginity, which is too impious to consider. This must be avoided, and thus we must at least affirm Mary's virginity during birth. This would fit the typology of Eze. 44:2, and thus also affirm her virginity after birth.

2. Immaculate Conception -- this teaches that Mary was saved by a retroactive application of Christ's saving work: at the moment of her conception she was saved by Christ and preserved from original sin, and cooperated with God's will in committing no personal sins, so that original sin would not pass to Christ. God prepared her as a holy vessel, for if Mary is stained with sin, then that means that God dwelt bodily in a body that was sinful, as his body was within Mary's body, and he took his flesh from Mary's flesh. How can God dwell within a sinful body? Further we know that God is a consuming fire, Heb. 12:29, but this fire burned in Mary's womb and she was not burned -- she is a typological fulfillment of the burning bush -- and she was not consumed because she bore no sin. One should also consider the special love that God has for Mary, for example the icon I have posted which shows God's special relationship to her. Imagine a being which God loves with the special love that a child gives to his mother, and this being raising up God himself as a child. The doctrine is functionally necessary.

This is a direct consequence of the former doctrine.

>Ok honestly Catholics, what is with the obsession with Mary? She isn’t really mentioned that much in the NT, but there seems to be as much focus on her as there is on Christ

Jesus and Mary have been linked from the beginning -- Genesis 3:15, to the end -- Revelation 12.

There is an indissoluble bond between the two, prophesied of old, fulfilled in time. The Father willed that the Incarnation should be preceded by Mary's acceptance, so that just as a woman (Eve) contributed to the spiritual death of the human race, so to a woman would contribute to its redemption and life.

Thus Mary is not only physically joined to her son, she is also joined to His saving work.

When we are baptized, we are born again as a child of God. 1 John 3:1.

As a result, Jesus, the Son of God, is truly our older brother.

His mother, or course, is Mary. If Jesus is our older brother, what does that make Mary in relation to us?

On the cross, Jesus literally gave His mother to us as *our* mother -- as seen in His declaration to John, the beloved disciple: "Behold your mother."

All Christians are 'beloved disciples' of the Lord. The Church reasons and teaches that the disciple John represented us all at the foot of the Cross. And Mary is now the spiritual mother of us all: "She is clearly the mother of the members of Christ," CCC 963

In short, it's a family affair. That's the Catholic view, and it truly is the biblical view.

See generally: https://www.catholic.com/magazine/print-edition/the-biblical-roots-of-the-marian-doctrines

>The Bank Act of 1844 divides the Bank of England into an issue department and a banking department. The former receives securities — principally government obligations — amounting to 14 million, and the entire metal hoard, of which not more than one-quarter is to consist of silver, and issues notes to the full amount of the total. In so far as these notes are not in the hands of the public, they are held in the banking department and, together with the small amount of coin required for daily use (about one million), constitute its ever ready reserve. The issue department gives the public gold for notes and notes for gold; the remaining transactions with the public are carried on by the banking department. Private banks in England and Wales authorised in 1844 to issue their own notes retained this privilege, but their note issue was fixed; if one of these banks ceases to issue its own notes, the Bank of England can increase its unbacked notes by two-thirds of the quota thus made available; in this way its issue was increased by 1892 from £14 to £16½ million (to be exact, £16,450,000).
>Thus, for every five pounds in gold which leave the bank treasury, a five-pound note returns to the issue department and is destroyed; for every five sovereigns going into the treasury a new five-pound note comes into circulation. In this manner, Overstone's ideal paper circulation, which strictly follows the laws of metallic circulation, is carried out in practice, and by this means, according to the advocates of the Currency Theory, crises are made impossible for all time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: >But in reality the separation of the Bank into two independent departments deprived its management of the possibility of freely utilising its entire available means at critical times, so that situations could arise in which the banking department might be on the verge of bankruptcy while the issue department still had intact several millions in gold and, in addition, its entire 14 million in securities. And this could take place so much more easily since there is a period in almost every crisis when heavy exports of gold take place which must be covered in the main by the metal reserve of the bank. But for every five pounds in gold which then go abroad, the domestic circulation is deprived of a five-pound note, so that the quantity of circulating medium is reduced precisely at a time when the largest quantity is most needed. The Bank Act of 1844 thus directly induces the entire commercial world forthwith to hoard a reserve fund of bank-notes at the outbreak of a crisis; in other words, to accelerate and intensify the crisis. By such artificial intensification of demand for money accommodation, that is, for means of payment at the decisive moment, and the simultaneous restriction of the supply the Bank Act drives the rate of interest to a hitherto unknown height during a crisis. Hence, instead of eliminating crises, the Act, on the contrary, intensifies them to a point where either the entire industrial world must go to pieces, or else the Bank Act.

Before the rise of modern Satanism in the 1960's there was definitely a wave of Satanism in France and Italy during the 19th century. Catholic saint Bartolo Longo had been involved in it before he converted. It was generally kind of linked to the intersection between liberal secularism, libertine bohemianism and spiritualism during that era.

Before that, while there was no organised Satanic religion per se, calling upon Satan and demons was an established albeit taboo aspect of Western occultism. Technically, most occultism and even demon summoning of that era took place within an Abrahamic framework, whereby demons were supposed to be bound to the will of the summoner by invoking God, but there were almost certainly people who believed they could get results by supplicating the powers of Hell directly.

>Many Christian doctrines raise difficult philosophical questions. For example, Christians have traditionally insisted that they worship a single God, while simultaneously identifying that God with a trinity comprised of three numerically distinct, fully divine persons: the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit. It is not easy to see how three divine persons add up to one God. Similarly, Christians have also asserted that a human man, Jesus of Nazareth, is also God-the-Son, the second person of the divine trinity. It is not easy to see how a human man, who is born, lives, and dies, could also be a fully divine being...

>Christian thinkers have always drawn on philosophy to help answer these kinds of questions... Over the course of the Patristic period, as the early Church successfully established its own intellectual framework, it formally defined the boundaries of Christian orthodoxy through a series of ecumenical councils...

>...For Christian thinkers, the already settled doctrines of Christian orthodoxy provide a normative framework within which this philosophical reflection occurs. For example, it is not open to an orthodox Christian thinker to dispel the logical problem of the Trinity (the problem of how God can be both three and one) by arguing that there is in fact no God, or that God is not triune, or that the Father and the Son are two stages in the temporal life of the one God. These theoretical options are ruled out by virtue of the philosopher’s own orthodox Christian commitments.

Pétain was a product of his time. A lot of outsiders don't really understand the faultlines that existed beneath French society during the Belle Epoque and the interwar years, faultlines that endure to this day. Pétain ideologically aligned with the rural bourgeoisie, who were conservative moralists with strong monarchist sympathies. Whilst Pétain wasn't particularly monarchist, he did oppose republicans on the matter of laicité and was an anti-Dreyfusard, one of the causes of his fallout with De Gaulle.

Basically Pétain was a reactionary (not necessarily a fascist although he aligned with them) and an antisemite who hanged with notables who were far more right wing than him. He detested the republic for three main reasons :
- The impoverishment of the rural classes by the industrial revolution and the perceived moral decline of an urban France that had lost agricultural values.
- The humiliation of the army during the Boulanger and Dreyfus affairs (DESU the republicans were absolutely in the fucking right on this one).
- The fact that the french republic purposefully undermined the political careers of military officers, even though he wanted to pursue one.

When Pétain takes power and self-coups the government, he believes himself to be negotiating an armistice with the German Empire 2.0 in which he can spare the army another humiliation by passing the blame onto the civilian government; He then tries to rebuild a more paternalistic agriarian France free from the 'corrupting' influences of urban centres and the republicans. He only realizes too late that he's just another Hitlerian puppet.

There were many reasons why Irish troops were enthusiastic to fight for US armies-whether Union or Confederate, but two of the main ones are:
>Citizenship/Respect
Irish people were not respected or well treated in the US, unsurprisingly; they arrived in droves as often monolingual impoverished and unskilled tenant farm labourers, with little to offer to urban centres on the East Coast. Military service was one fairly reliable path to "integration" or "acceptance" as Americans. Irish leaders in the Army were capitalised on by the US to take advantage of the Irish manpower pool, as was the case with Michael Corcoran and the 69th.
>Republican Tricks
Irish Revolutionary leaders encouraged their followers to enlist to gain military experience to be later used against Britain, as we saw in the Fenian Raids.

The US Civil War wasn't really about religion, and by this stage Irish Nationalism and Nationhood had an almost century old tradition of religious unity (United Irishmen, etc). So there wasn't too many reasons not to fight, in all honesty.

>The Locofocos (also Loco Focos or Loco-focos) were a faction of the Democratic Party in American politics that existed from 1835 until the mid-1840s.
>The faction, originally named the Equal Rights Party, was created in New York City as a protest against that city's regular Democratic organization ("Tammany Hall"). It contained a mixture of anti-Tammany Democrats and labor union veterans of the Working Men's Party, the latter of which had existed from 1828 to 1830.[1] They were vigorous advocates of laissez-faire and opponents of monopoly. Their leading intellectual was editorial writer William Leggett.
>In general, Locofocos supported Andrew Jackson and Van Buren, and were for free trade, greater circulation of specie, legal protections for labor unions and against paper money, financial speculation, and state banks. Among the prominent members of the faction were William Leggett, William Cullen Bryant, Alexander Ming Jr., John Commerford, Levi D. Slamm, Abram D. Smith, Henry K. Smith, Isaac S. Smith, Moses Jacques, Gorham Parks, and Walt Whitman (then a newspaper editor).
>Ralph Waldo Emerson said of the Locofocos: "The new race is stiff, heady, and rebellious; they are fanatics in freedom; they hate tolls, taxes, turnpikes, banks, hierarchies, governors, yea, almost all laws."[5]
